data.text: So‚Ä¶I attached this to my front fork and it was solid! I used one bolt and two zip-ties (included) along with three rubber guards to protect the frame or fork. Easy install and on there tight. I used the 4L dry bag and filled it with my sleep pad (sea to summit) my inflatable bad (sleeping pad fits inside it and protects it), my full fingered gloves, air pillow, small towel, bug bet and a few items and still had room to spare in there for a rain jacket or something else. Once I attached it to the harness and tightened the straps, that thing didn‚Äôt move an inch! We rode 15 miles and hit sleet for a little bit, all dry and nothing moved at all. Overall, great purchase. Will update if anything changes. I will say, I didn‚Äôt hit many bumps this time bc it was mainly paved. I will be doing gravel this week and will put it to the test.

data.text: these cages are used by many brands (Planet X Tarpaulin, Merida Gavel Cage a.k.a. Merida Travel Forkbag, Geosmina Cargo Cage Bag etc) The difference always in the drybags. data.text: I use Salsa Anything cages, a few comments, first I like the fact that all of these have a bottom portion that allows you to rest things on them and strap them down. I've got tons of different size nylon straps with buckles but have grown to prefer Voile rubber the best. Finally I change up bags. Grocery runs are random stuff sacks up to some Fish Pond dry/roll top stuff sacks, or even large volume if I'm bike packing with grand kids. Because I'm splitting time with kayaking I've got probably 10 different variations. Some might argue too many but I think..."options"
